title: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder Mimics Auditory Processing Disorder
chief_complaint: I have constant ringing in both ears and hearing loss. I have trouble hearing in quiet and noise, I get dizzy, and I'm sensitive to loud sounds. My memory is bad, I'm irritable, and I can't sleep.

problem_summary.course: Persistent symptoms since discharge; constant tinnitus.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus, dizziness/imbalance, memory loss, irritability, hyperacusis, sleep disturbance, blurred vision (transient).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe self-perceived hearing handicap (HHIA-S score 28); difficulty in diverse listening environments; anxiety in noisy places.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Plans to attend college; wants to listen in social situations with less effort and fatigue.

history.present_illness: Patient reports bilateral hearing loss and constant tinnitus following deployment. Also reports dizziness and memory issues.
history.otologic_history: History of blast exposures. No prior hearing protection use reported during blasts.
history.noise_exposure_history: Completed two tours in Iraq (OIF). Sustained 25+ blast exposures (IEDs, RPG, IRAM).
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with PTSD. Confirmed mild Traumatic Brain Injury (mTBI) with intracranial hematomas following RPG blast. Loss of consciousness reported.
history.prior_management: Previous diagnosis of PTSD; CT scan confirmed mTBI.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral slight hearing loss at 250-1000 Hz, rising to within normal limits at 2000-8000 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_Ear_Thresholds: 20-25 dB HL at 250-1000 Hz, improving to 0-10 dB HL at 2k-8k Hz
numeric_results.Left_Ear_Thresholds: 15-20 dB HL at 250-1000 Hz, improving to 0-5 dB HL at 2k-8k Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild SRT loss in the right ear, slight in the left. Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes within normal limits. Reflex decay negative.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Hearing Handicap Inventory for Adults (HHIA-S) indicated severe handicap.

history.present_illness: Follow-up to address functional hearing deficits despite normal peripheral sensitivity.
history.otologic_history: Previous evaluation showed normal peripheral hearing (high frequencies) but slight low-frequency loss.
history.prior_management: Referred for vestibular and APD evaluation.
history.patient_goals: Address difficulty hearing in noise and auditory memory issues.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Comprehensive vestibular evaluation (ocular motor, positional, caloric, rotational chair) was performed.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Words-in-Noise (WIN) test revealed severe SNR loss.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Adaptive Test of Temporal Resolution (ATTR) showed poor gap detection thresholds.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: LiSN-S (Listening in Spatialized Noise) showed deficits in using spatial and talker cues.

history.present_illness: 12-week follow-up after counseling to assess outcomes.
history.medical_psych_history: Received counseling through VA Mental Health Services for PTSD.
history.prior_management: Completed counseling on communication strategies and hearing conservation. Used disposable ear plugs. Completed Client-Oriented Scale of Improvement (COSI).
history.patient_goals: Review COSI goals: listening in social situations, attending college lectures, feeling less anxious in noisy environments.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: WIN score improved to 15.6 dB SNR but remains a severe SNR loss.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: ATTR gap detection threshold improved to 15.5 msec.

overall_audiologic_summary: Peripheral hearing sensitivity is essentially normal, with only slight low-frequency hearing loss and excellent word recognition in quiet. However, auditory processing evaluation reveals significant deficits in speech-in-noise performance, temporal resolution, and spatial processing. Results meet criteria for Auditory Processing Disorder (APD).
counseling_points: Your standard hearing test is mostly normal, but your brain is struggling to process complex sounds, which explains your difficulty in noise.
We recommend using an FM system (like the Phonak iSense) to help bring the speaker's voice directly to your ears in classrooms.
Communication strategies, such as facing the speaker and sitting in the front row, will be essential for your college courses.
Progressive Tinnitus Management (PTM) groups can help you learn to manage your reaction to the ringing in your ears.
notes_for_actor: Portray a young veteran who is frustrated that previous doctors might have said your hearing is 'fine' despite your struggles.
Exhibit signs of hyperacusis (sensitivity to loud noises) and mild anxiety/irritability consistent with PTSD.
You are motivated to go to college but worried about your ability to concentrate and hear the professor.
